description.narrative: Incrementally contribute to reducing all forms of gender based discrimination in Bangladesh by engendering the post 2015 development agenda and keeping gender equality, women’s empowerment and women’s human rights at the center while upholding the basic values of human rights, democracy and good governance.

Stöd till BMP (2018 - 2022)
Bangladesh Mahila Parishad (BMP) är en volontärbaserad icke-statlig organisation i Bangladesh som arbetar för kvinnors rättigheter. Organisationen bildades i Dhaka 1970 för att arbeta för kvinnors frigörelse. BMP har mer än 150 000 medlemmar och mer än 2000 gräsrotsnivåkommittéer utspridda över hela landet. Dess medlemmar kommer från alla samhällsskikt och består av alltifrån utbildade professionella kvinnor till lantbruksarbetande kvinnor.
BMP: s föreslagna projekt för perioden 2018-2022 syftar till att gradvis bidra till att minska alla former av könsbaserad diskriminering i Bangladesh genom att implementera genderfrågor i utvecklingsagendan efter 2015.
Det finns tre huvudmål som programmet kommer att arbeta för att uppnå: 1. Främja och skydda kvinnors mänskliga rättigheter, motstå alla former av våld mot kvinnor och flickor. 2. Främjande av kvinnors mänskliga rättigheter och arbeta för effektivt och meningsfullt deltagande av kvinnor i politiska processer och beslutsfattande för att stärka demokratin och god samhällsstyrning 3. Förstärkning och konsolidering av BMP: s kapacitet
Sverige har indikativt beslutat om stöd till projektet med en sammanlagd summa på 25 000 000 kronor.

Support to BMP (2018 - 2022)
Bangladesh Mahila Parishad (BMP) is a volunteer-based non-governmental organization in Bangladesh working for women’s rights. The organisation was established in Dhaka in 1970 to work for the emancipation of women. BMP has more than 150,000 members and more than 2000 grassroots level committees spread all over the country. Its members come from all walks of life and consist of urban educated professional women to the rural agricultural workers.
BMP's proposed project for the period 2018-2022 aims to incrementally contribute to reduce all forms of gender based discrimination in Bangladesh by engendering the post 2015 development agenda.
There are three main objectives that the programme will work towards: 1. Promote and protect women's human rights, resisting all forms of violence against women and girls. 2. Advocacy lobby for women's human rights and effective and meaningful participation of women in political process and decision making towards strengthening democracy and good governance 3. Strengthening and consolidating capacity of BMP
Sweden has indicated support to the Project with a total allocation of SEK 25 000 000.

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The progress of the project through the outputs show that the implementation of activities are on track. In 2018, BMP undertook 1,355 programmes out of which 915 and 441 implemented at the district and central levels respectively. The impact of programmes and activities related to the organization has been reflected in its growing acceptability in different section of the society. Through these programs BMP established effective interactions and engagement with women of different sections of society; BMP has developed new and young leadership capacity at different level of the organization; BMP could bring together a group of dedicated volunteers and activist at the grassroots and district levels for future leadership; women from different professional, marginalized and excluded group of the society have been showing solidarity with BMP as well as women’s movement. For example, BMP aggressively addressed the issue of gender based violence through multifarious program during this period. BMP has provided legal support to the victims of violence throughout the country. In 2018, BMP provided logistic support for legal activism and capacity building program to district branches. In 2018, a total no. of 760 cases were dealt by BMP which include both old and the new cases. The court delivered several verdicts in favor of the victims during this time. A notable achievement of BMP is a writ petition challenging the validity of the two-finger test in case of rape survivors medical examination filed by BMP along with other CSOs and 2 researchers in 2013. BMP and Bangladesh Legal Aid Services Trust jointly organized a sharing meeting for expert opinion on the filed writ petition in January 2018. Experts from relevant sectors (medical, legal, human rights activists, media, law enforcing agencies) were present. They opined for banning the nonscientific, irrational, inhuman and discriminatory two-finger test, and introduction of DNA test if necessary, and the change of rape law where perpetrator should have to take burden of proof and not the victim.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
